fields.name: The People's Temple
fields.location: Originally Indiana, later California, and finally Jonestown, Guyana
fields.symbols: The cross combined with socialist symbols
fields.core_beliefs: Combination of Christianity, socialism, and communal living
fields.rituals_practices: Communal meetings, faith healing, and revolutionary suicide drills
fields.hierarchy: Led by Jim Jones with a council of senior members
fields.membership: Thousands of members at its peak, diverse in terms of race and background
fields.significant_events: The mass suicide/murder at Jonestown in 1978
fields.public_perception: Initially seen as a progressive movement, later viewed as a dangerous cult
fields.controversies: Accusations of abuse, brainwashing, and mass suicide leading to the deaths of over 900 members

fields.name: The Manson Family
fields.symbols: Swastika and "X" carved into foreheads of some members
fields.core_beliefs: Apocalyptic race war ("Helter Skelter"), Charles Manson as the messianic figure
fields.rituals_practices: Drug use, orgies, and staged reenactments of the murders they intended to commit
fields.hierarchy: Led by Charles Manson, with a small group of loyal followers who carried out his orders
fields.membership: Dozens of core members, mainly young women, often recruited through manipulation and coercion
fields.significant_events: The Tate-LaBianca murders in 1969, resulting in the deaths of actress Sharon Tate and several others
fields.public_perception: Seen as a dangerous cult with a deranged leader, sensationalized by media
fields.controversies: Multiple brutal murders, manipulation of young followers, and Manson's use of psychological control

fields.name: Heaven's Gate
fields.symbols: UFO insignia, patches worn by members
fields.core_beliefs: Belief in extraterrestrial beings, that human bodies were vehicles for the soul, and that a spaceship would take them to a higher plane
fields.rituals_practices: Strict communal living, celibacy, and adherence to a strict regimen including a specific diet and dress code
fields.hierarchy: Led by Marshall Applewhite, known as "Do" after Nettles' death
fields.membership: About 39 core members at the time of their mass suicide
fields.significant_events: The mass suicide in March 1997, timed with the approach of the Hale-Bopp comet
fields.public_perception: Widely viewed as a bizarre and tragic cult, subject to intense media scrutiny
fields.controversies: The mass suicide, allegations of brainwashing, and extreme control over members' lives

fields.name: The Branch Davidians
fields.founder: Benjamin Roden (originally a splinter group from the Davidian movement founded by Victor Houteff)
fields.symbols: The Davidic star, various Christian and Old Testament symbols
fields.core_beliefs: An apocalyptic interpretation of the Bible, belief in the imminent end of the world, and the role of their leader as a prophet
fields.rituals_practices: Bible study, communal living, and stockpiling of weapons in preparation for the apocalypse
fields.hierarchy: Initially led by Benjamin Roden, later by David Koresh who assumed control in the 1980s
fields.membership: About 130 members at the time of the Waco siege, diverse in terms of background and nationality
fields.significant_events: The Waco siege in 1993, resulting in the deaths of 76 members after a 51-day standoff with the FBI
fields.public_perception: Divisive; some view them as victims of government overreach, while others see them as a dangerous, armed cult
fields.controversies: Allegations of child abuse, illegal weapons possession, and the tragic outcome of the Waco siege

fields.name: NXIVM
fields.symbols: The NXIVM logo, various symbols used in branding ceremonies
fields.core_beliefs: Self-improvement through a series of executive success programs and personal development workshops
fields.rituals_practices: Intensive workshops, branding ceremonies for members of the secret subgroup DOS, and a hierarchical structure of mentors and mentees
fields.hierarchy: Led by Keith Raniere, with key lieutenants like Allison Mack and Clare Bronfman
fields.membership: Around 16,000 participants over the years, with a core group of about 50 to 60 dedicated members
fields.significant_events: The arrest and conviction of Keith Raniere in 2018 for sex trafficking, forced labor, and racketeering
fields.public_perception: Seen as a dangerous cult masquerading as a self-help organization, heavily scrutinized after revelations of abuse and manipulation
fields.controversies: Allegations of sex trafficking, forced labor, psychological manipulation, and financial exploitation

fields.name: Children of God (now known as The Family International)
fields.location: Originally Huntington Beach, California, later international communes
fields.symbols: Various Christian symbols and imagery, the group's literature known as "Mo Letters"
fields.core_beliefs: Christian evangelical beliefs mixed with free love, communal living, and unorthodox sexual practices
fields.rituals_practices: Communal living, proselytizing ("flirty fishing" where members used sex to attract converts), and adherence to Berg's teachings
fields.hierarchy: Led by David Berg (known as Moses David), followed by his wife Karen Zerby (Queen Maria) after his death
fields.membership: Thousands of members globally at its peak, including many children born into the group
fields.significant_events: Various legal investigations, high-profile defections, and public accusations by former members
fields.public_perception: Seen as a controversial and abusive cult, with numerous allegations of sexual abuse and exploitation
fields.controversies: Allegations of child sexual abuse, exploitation of members, and psychological manipulation

fields.name: Rajneesh Movement (followers known as Rajneeshees)
fields.founder: Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh (later known as Osho)
fields.location: Originally Pune, India, later established Rajneeshpuram in Oregon, USA
fields.symbols: Mala beads with a locket containing Rajneesh's photo, orange/red clothing worn by followers
fields.core_beliefs: Combination of Eastern spirituality, meditation, and Western countercultural ideals; emphasis on personal enlightenment and free love
fields.rituals_practices: Dynamic meditation, communal living, and various therapies aimed at personal transformation
fields.hierarchy: Led by Rajneesh, with Ma Anand Sheela as his chief lieutenant during the Oregon period
fields.membership: Thousands of followers worldwide, with a significant number at the Oregon commune
fields.significant_events: The bioterror attack in 1984, poisoning 751 people in The Dalles, Oregon, and the subsequent legal battles and deportation of Rajneesh
fields.public_perception: Initially attracted interest for its unconventional practices, later viewed as dangerous and criminal after the bioterror attack and other illegal activities
fields.controversies: The bioterror attack, financial crimes, immigration fraud, and internal power struggles leading to violence and legal issues

fields.name: Love Has Won
fields.location: Colorado, USA; later Hawaii and California
fields.symbols: Various New Age and spiritual symbols, imagery of Amy Carlson as a divine figure
fields.core_beliefs: New Age spirituality, belief in Carlson as a divine being sent to save humanity, ascension doctrines
fields.rituals_practices: Daily livestreams, group prayers, and rituals focused on ascension and divine energy
fields.hierarchy: Led by Amy Carlson, with a core group of loyal followers known as the "First Contact Ground Crew Team"
fields.membership: A small, dedicated group of core members, with a broader online following
fields.significant_events: Death of Amy Carlson in 2021, subsequent legal and media scrutiny
fields.public_perception: Seen as a harmful and manipulative cult, subject to intense media scrutiny after Carlson's death
fields.controversies: Allegations of abuse, exploitation, and the bizarre circumstances surrounding Carlson's death and the handling of her body

fields.name: School of Prophets
fields.founder: Various leaders within the movement; commonly associated with televangelists and charismatic Christian preachers
fields.location: Various locations, primarily in the USA
fields.symbols: Christian symbols such as crosses, prophetic imagery
fields.core_beliefs: Emphasis on prophetic gifts, modern-day prophecy, and charismatic Christian teachings
fields.rituals_practices: Prophetic training, intense prayer sessions, speaking in tongues, and spiritual warfare practices
fields.hierarchy: Led by charismatic leaders, often self-proclaimed prophets, within independent ministries
fields.membership: Varies widely; can range from small groups to large congregations
fields.significant_events: Various prophecies, some of which have garnered media attention and scrutiny
fields.public_perception: Mixed; respected by some within the charismatic movement, viewed skeptically by mainstream Christianity and the public
fields.controversies: Failed prophecies, financial exploitation, and accusations of spiritual manipulation

fields.name: Angels' Landing
fields.core_beliefs: Perez claimed to be an angel with supernatural powers, used to manipulate followers
fields.rituals_practices: Various practices dictated by Perez, often involving manipulation and control over followers
fields.hierarchy: Led by Daniel Perez, who exerted total control over the group
fields.membership: A small group of followers, primarily women and children
fields.significant_events: Arrest and conviction of Perez in 2015 for multiple crimes, including sexual abuse and murder
fields.public_perception: Viewed as a dangerous and exploitative cult, widely condemned after Perez's crimes were revealed
fields.controversies: Sexual abuse, financial exploitation, and the murder of a follower to collect life insurance money

fields.name: Aum Shinrikyo (now known as Aleph)
fields.location: Japan, with branches in Russia and other countries
fields.symbols: Various religious and mystical symbols, including the Aum symbol
fields.core_beliefs: Syncretic mix of Buddhism, Hinduism, apocalyptic Christianity, and Asahara's teachings; belief in an impending apocalypse
fields.rituals_practices: Intense meditation, yoga, ascetic practices, and, later, preparations for violent acts
fields.hierarchy: Led by Shoko Asahara, with a strict hierarchical structure and inner circle of loyalists
fields.membership: Thousands of members at its peak, including highly educated individuals
fields.significant_events: Tokyo subway sarin attack in 1995, killing 13 and injuring thousands
fields.public_perception: Seen as a terrorist organization, widely condemned for its violent acts
fields.controversies: Numerous violent acts, including the Tokyo subway attack, assassination attempts, and illegal activities

fields.name: Matamoros Cult (also known as the Narcosatanists)
fields.symbols: Various occult symbols, ritualistic items used in ceremonies
fields.core_beliefs: Syncretic mix of Palo Mayombe, Santeria, and elements of Aztec religion; belief in human sacrifice for supernatural protection and power
fields.rituals_practices: Human sacrifice, animal sacrifice, ritualistic ceremonies involving the use of blood and body parts
fields.hierarchy: Led by Adolfo Constanzo, with a core group of loyal followers
fields.membership: Small group, mainly consisting of Constanzo's criminal associates
fields.significant_events: Discovery of the cult and its practices in 1989 after the murder of American student Mark Kilroy
fields.public_perception: Seen as a brutal and satanic cult, widely condemned for its gruesome practices
fields.controversies: Human sacrifice, drug trafficking, and various violent crimes

fields.name: Order of the Solar Temple
fields.founder: Joseph Di Mambro and Luc Jouret
fields.symbols: Solar and Templar imagery, robes, and ceremonial objects
fields.core_beliefs: Apocalyptic and esoteric beliefs, Templar revivalism, and preparation for spiritual transformation
fields.rituals_practices: Secret ceremonies, communal living, and preparation for the end times
fields.hierarchy: Led by Di Mambro and Jouret, with a strict hierarchical structure
fields.membership: Several hundred members across multiple countries
fields.significant_events: Mass murder-suicides in 1994 and 1995, resulting in the deaths of 74 members
fields.public_perception: Seen as a dangerous doomsday cult, heavily criticized after the mass deaths
fields.controversies: Mass murder-suicides, financial exploitation, and manipulative practices

fields.name: Russian Doomsday Cult (officially known as the True Russian Orthodox Church)
fields.core_beliefs: Apocalyptic beliefs, strict adherence to an extreme interpretation of Orthodox Christianity
fields.rituals_practices: Isolated communal living, preparation for the end times, extreme ascetic practices
fields.hierarchy: Led by Pyotr Kuznetsov, who claimed to have divine visions
fields.membership: Small group of followers, numbering around 30-35 at its peak
fields.significant_events: Members went into a cave in 2007 to await the apocalypse, resulting in a standoff with authorities
fields.public_perception: Viewed as a fringe and fanatical group, with significant media attention during the cave standoff
fields.controversies: Psychological manipulation, poor living conditions, and extreme beliefs leading to a dangerous standoff

fields.name: Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God
fields.symbols: Christian imagery, particularly focusing on the Ten Commandments
fields.core_beliefs: Apocalyptic Catholicism, strict adherence to the Ten Commandments, belief in imminent end of the world
fields.rituals_practices: Strict communal living, intense prayer, and preparation for the apocalypse
fields.hierarchy: Led by Mwerinde and Kibweteere, with a rigid hierarchical structure
fields.membership: Several thousand members at its peak
fields.significant_events: Mass murder-suicide in 2000, resulting in the deaths of over 700 members
fields.public_perception: Seen as a dangerous and tragic doomsday cult, heavily criticized after the mass deaths
fields.controversies: Mass murder-suicide, financial exploitation, and extreme manipulation of followers
